results.title: Give them a chance: forgotten refugees
results.brief_description: With an introduction by Duke Edinburgh, this film considers the plight of thousands of refugees who are still in camps in Europe, especially Greece. Many of them are without a country or relatives and pass their time in loneliness and misery in the squalor of the refugee camps. The United Nations Refugee Emergency Fund was set up for the purpose of helping these people. In Greece in the 1950’s, the Fund was able to assist the Greek Government in building homes and as a result many could hope for a better future.

results.title: Forgotten people
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description:
Shows the work of the Aborigines Advancement League (AAL), established in 1957. The film focuses particularly on Pastor Doug Nicholls and AAL President Bill Onus. They visit the settlements of Rumbaland, Robinvale and Dareton, showing the primitive conditions in which First Nations people are forced to live. Government housing is not provided at a sufficient rate. This film stresses the need for more positive action.
Sponsored by the Aborigines Advancement League (Victoria) in the wake of the 1967 Referendum, and featuring two of the League’s founding members in Nicholls and Onus.

results.title: Forgotten empire
results.creator_credit: Mushir Ahmad, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A survey of the remains of the ancient Viyayanagar Empire in Andhra State: the grand palaces, the magnificent gateways, beautiful frescoes and temples in the historical city of Viyayangar. This once mighty Hindu empire was founded in 1336 A.D. by two brothers-Hakka and Bukka-to serve as the strongest bastion of the south against recurrent invasions. The fateful battle of Talikota in 1565 brought ruin to the kingdom. Commentary written by Berkeley Hill and narrated by Romesh Thapar.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mushir Ahmad, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Forgotten Cinema
results.creator_credit: Anthony Buckley and Anthony Buckley Productions
results.brief_description: A history of theatrical film production in Australia including brief extracts from features illustrating development from the 19th Century to the postwar period. The problems of distribution of Australian films are explored, and well known film industry figures Ken G. Hall and Mrs. Elsa Chauvel discuss difficulties encountered.

results.title: The Forest: pulp logger
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The history of the timber industry in Eastern Canada. England deprived of its timber supplies after Napoleon’s conquest of Europe turned to Canada. The move west in America increased the demand for timber, and the advent of newspapers created a need for wood pulp. Today the highly mechanised timber industry makes Canada the largest exporter in the world.

results.title: Forest without spears
results.creator_credit: Lionel Hudson, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Bulolo Valley in New Guinea was once a mere hunting ground; now it is the home of the Commonwealth New Guinea Timbers, a company cutting 10 million square feet of Klinki pine a year. Compares pre-war mining operations by dredge and the forestry industry of today; the milling operations, growing seedling trees, felling mature ones; transport; transformation into the finished product; importance to the people of the area of the industry.

results.title: The Forest watchers
results.creator_credit: Peter Raymont, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Forest watchers tells us some remarkable things about one of our great natural resources. For example, nearly one half of Canada is forest, by the end of the century the supply might fall short of the demand. This film looks at the Canadian forests and the elements threatening them. These include the spruce budworm, air pollution and indiscriminate logging operations. Man is in the process of developing a new vision of the forest through the advent of remote sensing techniques. Written by Peter Raymont; photographed by Andreas Poulsson, Raymond Dumas; music by Larry Crosley.
